Ticket number 365 won
the June Week drawing for
a suit or' topcoat, according
to M. T. Medenbach, treasurer of June Week. The
drawing was made last
Wednesday at the Barn by
Sergeant Frank.
The topcoat or suit which
the winner may choose will
be furnished made to measure by _the Homeland Tailoring Company. The student holding the winning
number may secure his prize
by presenting his ticket to
Medenbach.
Wednesday's drawing
marks the culmination of a
successful attempt by the
June Week Committee to
raise money on the campus
for June Week,

EDITORIALS
BACKS AGAINST THE WALL
T. JOHNS will bring a team supported by an enviable record
to the Stadium tomorrow. The Johnnies have gone through
a strenuous season of eleven games and have lost none. Their
attack has shown ,great power, registering 117 goals, or over ten
per game while the defense has allowed only twenty shots to slip
into the netting, an average of less than two each game. Hopkins'
record cannot compare with this. The Jays have already suffered
two defeats at the hands of Army and Rutgers, teams which the
Johnnies have defeated.
Yet we feel that the experts who are predicting an overwhelming
St. Johns victory will be sorely disappointed. A St. Johns man told
us that "We are always afraid of Hopkins, because when a Hopkins
team gets the ball it always knows what to do with it. We may
have better ,individual players, but they know more lacrosse at Hopkins than anywhere in the country." That is the secret of Hopkins'
success at lacrosse over such a long period. Hopkins teams are
taught "what to do with the ball." It has been a long and tedious
task to instill team play into the new men on the squad, but by tomorrow a real Hopkins team should be ready to take the field.
But the team cannot win by itself. It needs the support of the
undergraduate body in this, its mOst „critical of games. We have
long bewailed the' fact that the energies of the Hopkins cheering
section (if it may be dignified by such an appellation) have been
directed mainly against the referee. The campus realizes that the
team is fighting with its back against The wall and it is up to the
rest of the students to be giving them support "on the side of the
line."
So far this year the undergraduates have seemed to be endeavoring to press upon the varsity men just how bad a lacrosse team
Hopkins has this year. They fail tel •realize that Olympic teams and
National Champions arc not to be expected every year and that off'
years are necessary phenornena. Instead, therefore, of encouraging
the team and helping it along in its Uphill struggle they have adopted
a supercilious, critical attitude which is unbecoming to say the least.
The Hopkins spirit is fine as long as the team is winning, but let it
suffer a few reverses and the attitude of the campus changes.
The team will be facing heavy odds in the game tomorrow. Yet
the old Hopkins' lacrosse knowledge, the heavy schedule of St. Johns,
and the psychological handicap under which a national title contender always has to labor, give the Jays a fighting chance for victory. It is up to the sidelines to increase that fighting chance.

MARKS, AGAIN
S another examination season rolls around we renew the plaint
for a more consistent system of working. The trouble with
e present condition lies in the fact that each individual instructor
follows his own interpretation of the system, with the result that
we have as many different standards as there are professors. One
man is not averse to giving a few tens, another believes that a ten
ahould mean perfection and so will only grade as high as nine-five.
A third believes that the others are much too lax and as a consequence tries to correct the general average by sprinkling only a few
eight-fives and eights into a garden of sixes and sevens.
Not only are the higher grades affected, but, what is much more
important, the difficulty of passing under some instructors is much
greater than under others. This may be due to the inherent difficulty of the subject. If so, the professor should realize the fact and
attempt to correct the discrepancy. We do not urge a laser system
should come
oi marking. We do urge, ,however, that the faculty
a more consistent agreement upon the requirements for the various,

At Willamette University that
youthful feeling which so pervades
our own freshmen and sophomores
evidently extends even to the seniors. "The senior class, in going
on their traditional 'flunk day' picnic, left two of its members behind
because these members had been
forcibly detained by-members of the
other classes, transported thirty
miles from town, and left tied in a
haymow." We cannot help but
think what ingenuity our own
underclassmen would have used in
a like predicament, a simple haymow, thirty miles, and ropes would
have been no cause for our Houdinis to miss the affair. The success
of the two class banquets proves it.

What is to be a true portrayal in
a movie of college life is to be made
on the eampus of the University of
Oregon. Executives heartily favor
the plan for the true representation
which it will give prospective students.
A more decided step than the
Hopkins "New Plan" is that advocated by Dr. Carl Franzen of the
University of Indiana. He advocates the complete abolition of the
third and fourth years of the undergraduate school. The two years
should be devoted to general courses
and these followed by work in the
graduate school or of professional
character.

EDITORIALS
BACKS AGAINST THE WALL
T. JOHNS will bring a team supported by an enviable record
to the Stadium tomorrow. The Johnnies have gone through
a strenuous season of eleven games and have lost none. Their
attack has shown ,great power, registering 117 goals, or over ten
per game while the defense has allowed only twenty shots to slip
into the netting, an average of less than two each game. Hopkins'
record cannot compare with this. The Jays have already suffered
two defeats at the hands of Army and Rutgers, teams which the
Johnnies have defeated.
Yet we feel that the experts who are predicting an overwhelming
St. Johns victory will be sorely disappointed. A St. Johns man told
us that "We are always afraid of Hopkins, because when a Hopkins
team gets the ball it always knows what to do with it. We may
have better ,individual players, but they know more lacrosse at Hopkins than anywhere in the country." That is the secret of Hopkins'
success at lacrosse over such a long period. Hopkins teams are
taught "what to do with the ball." It has been a long and tedious
task to instill team play into the new men on the squad, but by tomorrow a real Hopkins team should be ready to take the field.
But the team cannot win by itself. It needs the support of the
undergraduate body in this, its mOst „critical of games. We have
long bewailed the' fact that the energies of the Hopkins cheering
section (if it may be dignified by such an appellation) have been
directed mainly against the referee. The campus realizes that the
team is fighting with its back against The wall and it is up to the
rest of the students to be giving them support "on the side of the
line."
So far this year the undergraduates have seemed to be endeavoring to press upon the varsity men just how bad a lacrosse team
Hopkins has this year. They fail tel •realize that Olympic teams and
National Champions arc not to be expected every year and that off'
years are necessary phenornena. Instead, therefore, of encouraging
the team and helping it along in its Uphill struggle they have adopted
a supercilious, critical attitude which is unbecoming to say the least.
The Hopkins spirit is fine as long as the team is winning, but let it
suffer a few reverses and the attitude of the campus changes.
The team will be facing heavy odds in the game tomorrow. Yet
the old Hopkins' lacrosse knowledge, the heavy schedule of St. Johns,
and the psychological handicap under which a national title contender always has to labor, give the Jays a fighting chance for victory. It is up to the sidelines to increase that fighting chance.

MARKS, AGAIN
S another examination season rolls around we renew the plaint
for a more consistent system of working. The trouble with
e present condition lies in the fact that each individual instructor
follows his own interpretation of the system, with the result that
we have as many different standards as there are professors. One
man is not averse to giving a few tens, another believes that a ten
ahould mean perfection and so will only grade as high as nine-five.
A third believes that the others are much too lax and as a consequence tries to correct the general average by sprinkling only a few
eight-fives and eights into a garden of sixes and sevens.
Not only are the higher grades affected, but, what is much more
important, the difficulty of passing under some instructors is much
greater than under others. This may be due to the inherent difficulty of the subject. If so, the professor should realize the fact and
attempt to correct the discrepancy. We do not urge a laser system
should come
oi marking. We do urge, ,however, that the faculty

At Willamette University that
youthful feeling which so pervades
our own freshmen and sophomores
evidently extends even to the seniors. "The senior class, in going
on their traditional 'flunk day' picnic, left two of its members behind
because these members had been
forcibly detained by-members of the
other classes, transported thirty
miles from town, and left tied in a
haymow." We cannot help but
think what ingenuity our own
underclassmen would have used in
a like predicament, a simple haymow, thirty miles, and ropes would
have been no cause for our Houdinis to miss the affair. The success
of the two class banquets proves it.

What is to be a true portrayal in
a movie of college life is to be made
on the eampus of the University of
Oregon. Executives heartily favor
the plan for the true representation
which it will give prospective students.
A more decided step than the
Hopkins "New Plan" is that advocated by Dr. Carl Franzen of the
University of Indiana. He advocates the complete abolition of the
third and fourth years of the undergraduate school. The two years
should be devoted to general courses
and these followed by work in the
graduate school or of professional
character.
